awd_titl_txt: NRI: INT: COLLAB: Interactive and collaborative robot-assisted emergency evacuations
awd_abstract_narration:
Many emergencies require people to evacuate a building quickly. During an emergency, evacuees must make quick decisions, so they tend to rely on default decision making that may put them at risk, such as exiting the way they entered, following a crowd, or sheltering in place. When a crowd attempts to exit through a single exit, choke points and crowd congestion may impede the safe flow of evacuees, potentially resulting in a stampede of people and the loss of human lives. Mobile robots are increasingly being deployed as assistants on city streets and in hotels, shopping centers and hospitals. The future ubiquity of these systems offers an opportunity to change how people are evacuated from dangerous situations. In particular, when compared with traditional emergency infrastructure, such as fire alarms and smoke detectors, mobile robots can achieve better situation awareness and use this information to expedite evacuation and enhance safety. Additionally, mobile robots can be used in risky and life-threatening situations, such as chemical spills or active shooter scenarios, which present dangers to human first responders. 

This project aims to derive a scalable design framework and develop an embodied multi-robot evacuation system where multiple mobile robots, originally tasked for different purposes, serve as emergency evacuation first responders leading people to safety. In particular, multiple mobile robots efficiently coordinate with each other and actively interact with evacuees to maximize their egress. The project significantly contributes to the understanding of how people respond to a robots' directions and authoritative commands. Furthermore, the project implements these findings and demonstrates their effectiveness using real-world experiments with human subjects. Beyond emergency evacuation, the research findings can be extended to many other related areas, especially those involving cooperative robot teams that are embodied in an uncertain and dynamic physical world with the need to actively interact with humans; e.g., battlefield, law enforcement, urban transportation systems, manufacturing systems, rehabilitation and health management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of this project, we have made significant and important contributions to the use and development of evacuation robots. Our project has considered both the human-robot interaction challenges as well as the multi-robot control difficulties that arise when developing evacuation robots. For this project, we conducted experiments where human subjects were guided to an office cubicle by a robot and asked to read a paper. While they were reading, a smoke alarm sounded.  The subjects could then choose to follow the robot to a more distant and less familiar exit or exit the way they came. This experiment has allowed us to develop models capturing if and how robot-guided evacuees follow evacuation robots. These models and the resulting data will help other researchers develop evacuation robots and, ideally, save lives. Our work has also verified the similarity between evacuation experiments conducted using virtual reality and those conducted in the real world. Our results demonstrate that models of evacuee behavior created in virtual reality are like how people behavior in the real world. These results suggests that virtual reality could be a key tool for conducting robot-guided emergency evacuation experiments. Moreover, work has led to increasing interest in robot-guided emergency evacuation as evidenced by the recent surge of robot/intelligent evacuation papers.

We have also sought to expand how robots guide evacuees to safe locations. Most of the work (including ours) on robot-assisted human evacuation has focused on single-robot scenarios. We have pioneered the study of the problem of controlling a group of mobile robots to collaboratively guide a group of humans to a particular exit during an emergency evacuation. We have explored using general models of human motion (such as the social force model) to synthesize an optimal controller which guarantees that the evacuees will be efficiently driven to the exits. In addition, multi-robot optimal motion planning in an evacuee-crowed environment is a computationally challenging problem. We have developed a novel numerical algorithm to identify the optimal solutions where no robot can unilaterally reduce its traveling time without extending others’. Experiments on an indoor multi-robot platform and computer simulations show the anytime property of the proposed algorithm; i.e., it is able to quickly return a control policy that safely steers the robots to their goal regions and it keeps improving policy optimality if more time is given. Moreover, during an evacuation, robots need to infer the intent and preferences of humans to effectively coordinate with them. We have developed a novel method for multi-agent behavior inference from distributed and streaming demonstrations. Our method formally guarantees that the distributed learners will achieve consensus on the individual’s reward functions, constraints, and policies.
